At-a-Glance: A tight, contiguous brood pattern signals a healthy queen and good conditions. Diagnosing gaps early prevents cascades into swarm pressure, disease, or poor overwintering.
Why it Matters: Patchy brood can indicate queen failure, varroa pressure, nutrition gaps, or chilling.
Fast diagnosis avoids wasted weeks in peak season.
Clear remediation plans stabilise productivity and temperament.
Objectives: Differentiate normal brood patch boundaries from pathological spotty patterns.
Link each defect to likely causes and a standard fix.
Record brood quality every inspection to spot trends.
What Good Looks Like: Solid ‘football-shaped’ brood area with eggs, larvae, and capped brood in concentric rings.
Minimal drone scatter in worker cells, good pollen rim and open cells for eggs.
Calm bees with minimal pinging under light smoke.
Step-by-Step: 1) Observe pattern: centre to edges, note any scattered empty cells or perforations.
2) Check eggs/larvae density and age gradient; confirm queenright.
3) Review environment: nectar/pollen intake, temperature, wet frames, space.
4) Health screen: spot signs of varroa (DWV), chalkbrood, foulbrood cues.
5) Decide action: nutrition (feed/pollen), space (add comb), varroa treatment, or requeen.
6) Recheck in 7–10 days; compare photos and notes.
Seasonality & Climate: Cold snaps and damp springs create chilled brood and patchiness.
Late summer dearth backfills brood nest and disrupts pattern.
Data & Thresholds: Spotty brood with >10–15 percent empties across the patch suggests intervention.
Drone-laying in worker cells or shotgun pattern often indicates queen failure or varroa stress.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Scattered capped brood with chewed cappings -> Varroa/virus suspected -> Quantify mites -> Treat per plan.
Symptom: Eggs absent but queen seen -> Age or pheromone decline -> Consider requeening.
Symptom: Backfilled nest -> Add space and drawn comb; super; consider split.
Symptom: Twisted larvae/melted look -> Suspect EFB -> Isolate and report per rules.
Common Pitfalls: Confusing young queen ramp-up with chronic spotty brood.
Treating varroa without verifying with a quantitative test.
Ignoring nutrition while chasing queen issues.
Tools & Techniques: Frame photo log, magnifier or head torch, brood thermometer if desired.
Tick-box inspection sheet to score brood quality.
Safety & Compliance: Biosecurity when moving frames between colonies.
Communications: Explain to helpers the difference between new-queen ramp-up and failure.
Further Reading: Inspectorate photo guides to brood diseases.
Notes: Keep a small laminated brood score card in your kit to standardise notes.
